replies.author: @Max91019
replies.text:
In Ukraine there are too strict restrictions on the Russian language when it comes to  education (which is a mistake) system but there is no ban on the Russian language as such. Why distort reality so much only in order to promote the theses of Russian ultranationalists? And why is it not taken into account that there are strict restrictions and social stigma against everything Ukrainian in Russia, Crimea and the territories occupied by Russia in Ukraine. In fact, many Russian speakers in Ukraine are fighting not for the right to use the Russian language but for the right for rincipled refusal to use Ukrainian, which from the point of view of millions of Russians and self-hating Ukrainians  is a backward and rural language that must disappear. Ukrainians are less numerous, more poor materially, historically stateless unlike Russians who own Large Empire with possessions and territories in 2 continents. But millions views Russians as innocent victims and Ukrainians as evil oppressors!

 People like you are obsessed to talk about "banderites". Right wing Ukrainian nationalism is not something good. As an Ukrainian myself I think that Ukraine need centre left anti-imperialist nationalism which would be not just against Russians hegemony but also against dependency from the West and against privilege of Ukrainian ruling class. But Russian far right nationalism which is rooted in political and cultural traditions of czarist Russia is much worse, had more blood on its hand historically (millions were killed due to Russian expansionism in XV-XIX century in order to install Russian supremacy) and it's THE MAIN obstacle to peaceful coexistence between Ukrainians and Russians!

Russians wants to preserve their privileges while Ukrainians who are less numerous, historically stateless and poor materially. Stupid and too much anti-russian politics of Ukrainian ruling class is not justification for russian brutality. Nicholas II, Stolypin, Dugin, Putin and other far right russian ultranationalists and ukrainephobes are not better than Bandera. And Yes being pro-ukrainian doesn't mean to be pro-western. As an Ukrainian I view dependency from the West as lesser evil but STILL evil than dependency from Russia. We Ukrainians as historically stateless people in periphery of global capitalist system are marginalized in relation to both Russia and the West.

author: @BringBackGulags
text: Well, my parents lived through the Soviet Union and they would never ever wish it to have collapsed. My father straight up loved Communism and my mother's only complaint is that sometimes the jews were held back from high positions (take that fascists) and she would have liked more free speech. But no one would say the 90s or even the 21st century is better. My uncle lived through it, he'll tell you how much cheaper everything was. Even my Jewish grandfather, who was a factory director, was offered a job with living expenses paid in America, and he declined because he was a proud Soviet. His apartment didnt have hot water, and he never once complained even though his position would afford him the influence. Such proud and grateful people lived in the USSR. All my relatives who died during WW2 volunteered to defend their ungrateful great-grandchildren who grew up on trash tv from America, Macdonalds, and fables about Holodomor.

replies.text: @Lawns-Are-Fun While I do acknowledge what you said, it's just not right to slander every Ukrainian having an opposing towards communism as a Banderite or brainwashed by Banderites.  Whether the caller falls into those categories will remain a question since they didn't ask him directly.  But he said nothing ahistorical about the events in Ukraine in 1918.  What he said was not a revisionist Banderite historical account but mainstream accepted history.  He got slammed with the "Banderite" label while talking about a 1918 socialist independence movement crushed by bolsheviks.  The only thing that proved is the panel either did not understand what he was talking about or they themselves have a revisionist history of events in Ukraine in 1918.

replies.author: @ilyamuromets317
replies.text: @itsnony77 That's not quite true. Ukrainian SSR was the Socialist Republic and it allied with, and fought alongside the Soviet forces. Petlyura's short-lived People's Republic (which existed only in Western Ukraine) was defeated by the Poles before 'joining forces' with them and effectively becoming a Polish proxy army. Then you had the Hetman's forces, allied with the White Army, and that's before we get to the Anarchists led by Makhno. All of these armies were chaotically fighting one another, as is well covered by Bulgakov in 'The White Guard'.  This was a very complicated civil conflict- one front on the much wider Russian civil war- and not an 'invasion', as it is misrepresented in Ukrainian history books today.

replies.author: @itsnony77
replies.text: @ilyamuromets317 Yes it was very complex and I wouldn't call it an invasion either.  Nor would I call it a civil war.  That's a soviet perspective.  However you want to call the events of 1918, fact is the independence movement was initiated by Ukrainian socialists only to end up as part of the Soviet Republic.  So I'm not quite sure what part of what I said you disagree with other than the caller labeling it an "invasion".  That doesn't justify slandering him as Banderite.  If that's Banderite revisionism most western historians on this topic should be deemed Banderites too.

replies.author: @nikolay-e8l
replies.text:
@itsnony77 the Bolsheviks did invade Ukraine but again its way more complicated that what history will portray it as. The Bolsheviks were fighting against the white army and many white army elements were within the former Russian territories like the Baltics, Belarus, Ukraine, the Caucasus, and in Central Asia and wider Siberia. The Bolsheviks were focused on there internal struggles which means its former territories which they had feared would become buffer states by Poland and Germany. And after the Soviet Polish war the Polish invaded and occupied parts of modern day Ukraine and Belarus. And Ukraine was split into different factions. You the the communist republics in the east. Then you had the Ukrainian peoples republics, and then west Ukrainian peoples republics which was mostly under Polish rule to counter balance the communist forces. Many of the Ukrainian western republics. To understand the essence of the processes taking place in Ukraine, it is necessary to clearly understand how, under what influence and from what ethnic groups Ukrainian society was formed. Today, official Ukrainian propaganda claims that Ukraine is a unitary state in which only Ukrainians live, with a small interspersing of other ethnic groups united in a monolithic Ukrainian nation. All this is a fiction, no Ukrainian nation exists, Ukraine is a patchwork, woven in different historical eras from different nations that were part of different civilizations. Galicia after the collapse of Kievan Rus more than 700 years before its accession by Stalin in the 1939 year was at the margins of Western civilization as an oppressed people and has long lost its Russian roots. The center of Ukraine for a long time was under Polish rule, acquired the specific features of a mixture of Russian and Polish culture with its originality, and in the 17th century it became part of the Russian Empire. Southeast - the original Russian land, the Wild Field, mastered by the administration of the Russian Empire in the XVIII century under the leadership of Prince Potemkin.

The Bolsheviks united all these territories into the Ukrainian Republic, which, with the collapse of the Union, became an independent state. So in one state on occasion there were different peoples with different historical destinies, with different mentality and national values ‚Äã‚Äãand diametrically opposite ideas about their future. At the same time, it should be noted that in these three megaregions, population groups that are fundamentally different in their social composition have developed. One the of main factions that belonged to the Ukranain nationalist movement was the OUN. more extreme Ukrainian nationalist in Russian-controlled Ukraine, Mykola Mikhnovs‚Äôkyi, who would preach a worldview that saw a Ukrainian race surrounded by enemies that needed to be eliminated. He inserted 19th century Social Darwinism and scientific racism into Ukrainian nationalism, writing in the majority Russian city of Kharkov. He labelled ‚ÄúRussians, Poles, Magyars, Romanians and Jews as enemies of Ukraine‚Äù (as long as they ruled or exploited Ukrainians) and hoped to create a Ukrainian state stretching from the Caucuses to the Carpathian Mountains. His Ten Commandments of the UNP (Ukrainian National Party) founded in 1904 would be a major influence on the OUN. It included such memorable lines as ‚ÄúDo not marry a foreign woman because your children will become your enemies.‚Äù Elsewhere Mikhnovs‚Äôkyi wrote ‚ÄúUkraine for Ukrainians, and as long as even one alien enemy remains on our territory, we are not allowed to lay down our arms.‚Äù

replies.author: @nikolay-e8l
replies.text: @itsnony77 However Ukraine became a battleground between the Red Army, the Germans, the Polish, and the white Russian counter-revolutionary forces. Also fighting were the West Ukrainian army, Petlura‚Äôs forces, the forces of the Ukrainian Anarchist Makhno, and various bandit warlords and Cossacks. Kiev would change hands more then a dozen times. Initially the Ukrainian People‚Äôs Republic rejected the Soviet ultimatum to allow the Red Army to pass through to attack the white forces. However war was avoided for a couple months. Soon the Red Army was occupying Kiev as the Rada lacked popular support. People wanted land reform not Ukrainization, something viewed as annoyance by many Russian speakers. The Rada forces had deserted to the Red Army. However the Soviets would control Kiev for only three weeks. The Rada turned to the Germany and Austria who recognized the UNR. The Germans invaded Ukraine forcing the Red army to withdraw. Symon Petliura‚Äôs forces took power. In April 1918, the Germans disbanded the Rada and installed a puppet Government under Hetman Skorpadsky. Germany was under an economic blockade with its people facing starvation. The Germans proceeded to loot Ukraine‚Äôs grain, angering the peasants. In November 1918 the German military collapsed and they abandoned Ukraine. Skorpadsky retreated with them. Petliura and the new Rada government called ‚ÄúThe Directorate‚Äù seized power in Kiev yet again before being forced out by the Red Army. As Petliura‚Äôs forces retreated they carried out massive pogroms against the Jews. Petliura‚Äôs forces often dressed up as communist forces to carry out these Pogroms murdering the communist sympathizers who came to greet them first, and then spending days robbing, raping, and murdering the rest of the Jews. With Germany out of the war, Britain and France were free to back the even more bloodthirsty white General Denikin in his attempt to destroy the Soviet Union. Ironically Denikin was a Russian nationalist who viewed Ukraine as inseparable from Russia. Denikin‚Äôs forces carried out equally horrific pogroms. Petliura allied with Denikin and then with Poland.

replies.author: @beibotanov

replies.author: @DranguDghu
replies.text: @beibotanov the bad being the economic changes that came with perestroika and supposedly glasnost. You know why? Cause capitalist economic policies starting from 1956 and kruschevite revisionism caused them. There is a tragic western documentary just before the collapse. There are two sides represented. Those that say "i am not a communist" and he actually described communism as what he wanted,but because of the gorbachevite alteration he didnt like it, and the second was people actually saying "i like communism" and they continued by saying that they trust Gorbi and his policies, and that with perestroika and glasnost the problem caused would be solved. Both groups represented in the documentary were politically uneducated, but the confusion that perestroika and "glasnost" caused by the C. P. was visible.

replies.author: @beibotanov
replies.text: @DranguDghu a common Stalinist mythology. The truth is real socialism was quite uncomfortable to live in. You have 8 hour work day just to waste an hour or two a day to queuing to "get" something "thrown out" in the shops. Having the feeling of unfairness, when seeing or hearing about people able to skip through the queues, to steal the "deficit" and sell it with market price, the luxury these kinds of people, like vegetable depot's bosses, supposedly live in. My friend's mum, being a child in the early 80's, had to wake up 4-5 a.m. to go through the milk line before her school. And there were many other aspects, such as crass service sector workers. I always project these stories upon myself, and would not really liked to live this way. The only thing I can mention that is much worse now is in housing, thanks to our wise Gov't overheating the estate market

Basically, the question was: "Do want everything good without everything bad?"

replies.author: @beibotanov
@DranguDghu
replies.text: @beibotanov This is a classic common western cold war plain lie. Scarcity in the USSR on goods existed in time of WW1, civil war (14 foreign countries invaded young RSFSR plus the Whites, and at some points Greens and Blacks), WW2 and finally the perestroika. You can add to that the facts of the various economic sanctions on the USSR,military funding for the preservation of the country caused again by foreign enemies, millions of work force and infrastructure lost in these wars etc As for the lines, do not forget US had lines too, and still has, with a major difference: in the end of the line in the US people have (and had) to pay a lot. Also, i really wonder how most of the countries on earth (except the US, Europe and 2-3 more countries) are poor. Uganda, Zimbabwe, Malaisia, Haiti and almost all arabic, african, south african, east countries are POOR? Why capitalism does not work for them>? if capitalism works like that, well, we dont like it. Also being from Greece, a country that has many immigrants from ex-USSR, believe me, i ve spoken with many of them, not only "one friends mum".

replies.author: @DranguDghu
replies.text: @beibotanov as for the referendum, renewed and sovereign was about capitalist reforms that took place. For example you can see that in the first years of USSR, rights and freedoms of all nationalities were guaranteed, that is why USSR publishes books on over 150 native languages for example. Also as exactly happened in the recent Greek referendum, ALL people i know were in a fake dilemma of no and yes about taking money from IMF and voted no, but if you read carefully, while everyone voted for No Imf funding, they turned it in" Not on this particular imf funding " And imposed another, worse. In this logic, most people of the USSR voted for the part of the preservation of the USSR and not for the sovereignty etc in the way you think, but in the way they had it in the years before capitalist corrosion of the economy, just as greeks voted for a general NO and not a no to this particular only IMF funding

This is the problem socialism tries to solve, As capitalism DID solve SOME of the feudal problems before.

author: @Tariq-oj5zz
text:
Forgive me if I sound incredibly ignorant, All I did was read the principles of communism by Engels.

Speaking of the USSR's vs. China's Communist Parties, is the American Communist Party's goal to grow through a period of industrialization in disadvantaged areas through capitalism, or is it to go for centrally planned 5 year plans all at once? Chinese people do far better than many Americans, we leave people on the street because they're disabled, poor, elderly, children, single parents etc. when there could be enough productive force to create a 100% employment rate, we could easily abolish poverty their way, but I prefer ML economics.

 I would have never supported this 2 years ago, but Elon's  DOGE is straight up radicalizing all those that rely on the government.

replies.author: @Tariq-oj5zz
@therollerlollerman
replies.text:
@Tariq-oj5zz In China you can fiercely criticize gov't policies and force a change in them, not the political system. In the US you can criticize the political system as much as you want as an escape valve, just don't expect any policy changes.

Also, the poverty alleviation efforts were entirely state-driven and planned, targeted at less wealthy regions and the countryside that market forces would not even bother investing in because the margins aren't attractive enough. It's the rich coastal urban areas in China that are more capitalistic and market driven, as a way to generate and concentrate wealth. Here, the people's mindsets are more greedy, pro-western and status chasing. Fortunately there is still the political monopoly of the Communist Party that forces redistribution to the places feeding and sustaining their opulent lifestyles.

author: @volition2015
text:
I was also a Soviet kid in the 80's and remember visiting our relatives in Ukraine in 1990. Going to a toy store in Mykolaiv was an experience. There were new car models, trucks, toy guns, water pistols, electronics, all kinds of stuff. I've never seen half of those things in my hometown in Russia. 

At the same time I understand why many Ukrainians, especially young people, hate literally everything about Soviet Union (derogatory term "sovok" is often used). Since 1987 they were surrounded by anti-communist and anti-Soviet messaging 24/7. Literature, movies, songs, mass media, museums, internet, political rhetoric. All of that went into overdrive after 2014. And since 2022 USSR is being deliberately linked to Putin's Russia and the horrors of war. Anticommunism is being burned into the Ukrainian identity.  

When it comes to Ukrainian nationalism, it's much bigger than OUN(b) aka "banderites". Some members were sympathetic to national-socialism and Hitler's ideas, but majority were not Nazis in my opinion.

replies.author: @OlgaRykov
replies.text: The uneducated youth erroneously think that perestroika that they have observed is Soviet Union and instead of calling it what it is - perestroika - they call it sovok. But what they actually imagine in their heads when they say it is not Soviet Union, it's perestroika.

author: @itsnony77
text: This debate lacked some nuance.  Caller gets accused of having been indoctrinated by Banderites.  In reality not all anti-communist sentiment in Ukraine has always been exclusively Banderite nor iis all of anti-communist sentiment today in Ukraine exclusively Banderite in origin.  Some people just don't like communism.   Some people interpret the events of 1918 as an invasion without resorting to Banderite indoctrination.  You should be more careful throwing these accusations around.  It's quite patronizing.  It really muddied an otherwise interesting debate.

replies.author: @OlgaRykov
replies.text: Nah, pretty much all are indoctrinated into Banderite ideology. Bandera having been a western intelligence agency asset and appointed to fulfil the goal of brainwashing eastern european slavs into hating their communist brethren and edging on a civil war in the form of collaboration with yahtzee invaders so that russians k i l l each other, much like today, while the yahtzees unalive them as well - that's all banderite ideology. Much like I did, many russians/ukrainians/belarussians have no clue what the roots of their dislike of USSR is, and then when you grow up and read the declassified cia documents on using uk rain ian nationalism to spark civil unrest and even war in USSR you begin to understand you're just a cog in the banderite ideology. So yeah, it's ALL banderite ideology, whether the pawn is aware of it or not.

replies.author: @therollerlollerman
replies.text: @OlgaRykov the CIA refined the original notsee strategy on Banderites by helping BY/UA/RU nationalists ally with each other to overthrow the Soviet Union then began funding one side (the Ukrainian one) to start fighting against the rest. Much less direct from the CIA and more confusing for the belligerents involved

replies.author: @redsouth2715
replies.text:
They explained themselves clearly. Lots of people gripe over the dinner table about this or that problem, sure, there might be some random people who, as you put it, just happened to not like communism for completely obscure reasons, but that kind of abstract individualism, itself, lacks nuance. When you take all the people who resented communism so much that they believed the State should be overthrown, the people who were motivated to political action at a scale that‚Äôs relevant historically, the actual anti-Communists, and put them all together, you get the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists. In reality, the OUN is the political force that emerged as the expression of anti-communism within Ukraine.

The caller just dismissed Bandera as a boogie man (which alone demonstrates a high degree of indoctrination, or bad faith), but if his anti-Communist nationalism is not rooted in Banderist mythology, then why could he not simply articulate a different political tradition to which he aligns? One separate, distinct and critical of Banderism and the OUN. How can a Ukrainian make a case against communism without addressing the issue that fascism was the historical alternative.

replies.author: @OlgaRykov
replies.text: @therollerlollerman Strangely, I don't see my reply that you replied to. Do you see it?

replies.author: @itsnony77
replies.text: ‚Äã@redsouth2715 I am starting to think you were on the panel because you are making the exact same mistake again.  The caller never "dismissed Bandera as a boogie man".  Listen to what he said, you didn't listen then and you are not listening now.  He said "We were talking about one period (being the Ukrainian state in 1918).  For some reason you're focused on the Banderites which I never even mentioned.If it fits your boogie man go for it!" The caller was speaking about the events of 1918 and you guys start ranting about Bandera.  Totally anachronistic.  The caller was indicating this and pointing out your anachronism being a strawman/boogie man.  At least this is how I understood it.  Maybe if he wasn't interrupted and talked over so much this could have been cleared up.  This would also have cleared up the invalidity of your other argument.  Trying to explain away the Tsentralna Rada issuing its Fourth Universal (dated 22 January 1918) as a fascist movement is just ridiculous.  I'm sure caller would have cleared this up to you if you let him talk. Historically they were by majority socialists.  Not obscurely anti-communist individuals, nor fascists. Patriotic Ukrainian socialists.  I'm surprised you're doubling down on this instead of accepting the fact calling anyone with an opposing view towards communism either in a historical or actual context fascist - just because they're Ukrainian - is a rather silly argument,  Not to mention patronizing af.  Maybe he is a Banderite or indoctrinated by it, I don't know to be fair.  But you could have asked him instead of throwing these accusations in an anachronistic context.  Even in modern context this "all anti-communist sentiment is fascist in nature" is nonsensical.  I could give you a long list of European countries which have resentment towards communism expressed within socialist movements.  Both historical and today.  The 1918 Ukrainian independence movement was initiated by a patriotic Ukrainian SOCIALIST movement.  This is a historical fact.  So yes,  despite what Noah says you can discuss this topic without addressing Bandera.  The original opposition towards Russian communism was socialist not fascist.  In my opinion communism wasn't the reason for the opposition rather than it being perceived as invasive and going against their nationalist feelings. Now, you can try to forcibly retro-project Banderism onto it as much as you want it doesn't make you sound any more intelligent.  It only further proves the historical lack of understanding of events in that specific timeframe.  Sure we can debate whether these socialist movements with a communist allergy within Europe are truly socialist in nature.  We might even agree on some points I'm sure but this is beside the topic raised here.  Outside of this topic I admit I chuckled a bit when Noah depicted China as an illustration of communist success.  China today is as far removed from communism as it is from neo-liberalism.  Yes it's successful looking at GDP growth but the (semii--)proletariat in China is still suffering under a neo-liberal policy of blind pursuit of capitalist gain.

replies.author: @itsnony77
replies.text: @OlgaRykov I am not seeing your reply

replies.author: @linusmayden8465
replies.text: Reality is that there were different competing factions in Ukraine, Socialist, Anarchists, Bolsheviks, the Communist Ukrainians already existed in Odessa and Kharkov at municipal levels before the USSR invaded.

replies.author: @itsnony77
replies.text: @linusmayden8465 Thank you for sharing the detailed account of events . You seem very knowledgeable I think this would be a great topic on this show.

replies.author: @redsouth2715
replies.text:
@itsnony77 Short lived, unstable attempts to build a state, in the midst of a power vacuum and subsequent civil War, never had any prospect of leading to Ukrainian sovereignty. This patriotic Ukrainian socialist blah blah blah is all fantasy. Yes, there were a number of factions/gangs, just as there were in Russia, but they had only two options, align with the Bolsheviks and engage in a genuine socialist project or become proxies of imperialist reaction. And, just as in Russia, those who were serious about popular power and land reform simply joined the Bolsheviks, the rest became reactionary. It was in fact the Soviet Union that gave the Ukraine people a nation and it was the Soviet economy that gave them the sovereignty from Western imperialism necessary for rapid economic development, up to manufacturing gas turbines, rocket motors and other the cutting edge technology. Without it, Ukraine would‚Äôve been completely cucked, exporting raw commodities to the West.

No idea if this guy is a fascist or not, a lot of people are just very naive.

replies.author: @itsnony77
replies.text: @redsouth2715 I agree there was no chance for the socialist Ukrainian state to succeed given the forces at play at that time.  Where I disagree is the very one-sided perspective you apply.  Not only the Western forces at play in that era were imperialistic, so was the bolshevik force. The tactics used were no different from the colonialism applied by the West.  The Ukrainians weren't exactly given sovereignty they became part of the Soviet project with any remnants of Ukrainian nationalism getting crushed by force.

replies.author: @redsouth2715
replies.text:
@itsnony77 The Soviet Union was qualitatively different to the colonial powers. They didn‚Äôt crush Ukrainian nationalism, they compromise with it, hence the granting of additional territories and massive economic investment. They did crushed forces opposed to the revolution, who were all receiving support from foreign powers.

Try to name a Western colony that could produce rocket motors, if they were so similar?

replies.author: @itsnony77
replies.text: @redsouth2715 Economic growth is no argument whatsoever in deciding whether this was colonialism or not.  It was clearly a colonialist project.  Once the bolsheviks figured out these Ukrainian socialists in the Rada were unwilling to align with Bolshevism they took Kharkiv.  If they had no colonial intention they could have backed that early socialist state despite non-alignment.  As history shows, a non-aligned alliance was simply not negotiable and force was applied to gain complete political control.

replies.author: @redsouth2715
@ilyamuromets317
replies.text: @itsnony77 which Socialist State 'despite non-alignment'? There wasn't one. Petlyura was crushed by the Poles and then agreed to become a proxy for them. Makhno never stood a chance. The Hetman was with the Whites, and the UkSSR was aligned with the Bolsheviks. There were no other major players. Were the Bolsheviks supposed to just hand Kiev over to the Poles? It's absurd.
